description:
Micropterus dolomieu, commonly known as the smallmouth bass, is a species of freshwater fish that belongs to the sunfish family, Centrarchidae. It is native to the eastern and central United States and southeastern Canada.

The smallmouth bass is a medium-sized fish, typically ranging from 30 to 50 centimeters (12 to 20 inches) in length and weighing 0.7 to 3.2 kilograms (1.5 to 7 pounds). It has a slender, streamlined body with a large, terminal mouth and a distinct jaw that extends past the eye. The dorsal fin is divided into two parts, with the anterior portion having 9-11 spines and the posterior portion having 13-15 soft rays. The coloration of the smallmouth bass can vary, but it is generally olive-green or brown on the back, with dark vertical bars or blotches along the sides, and a white or pale belly.

Smallmouth bass are found in clear, cool, and well-oxygenated rivers, streams, and lakes with rocky or gravel substrates. They are carnivorous and primarily feed on a variety of small fish, crayfish, and aquatic insects. The species is known for its impressive fighting ability and is highly prized by recreational anglers.
